Newfoundland - General 15. Bond's real reason for refusing to visit Ottawa. Nfld. wishes to publish entire correspondence re American question: Lord Elgin refuses consent. We began with a desire to force America to adopt Bond Hay Convention...have now drifted away from that, & at present desire to make fishery impossible for Americans. 2/5 of men employed in fishery, work for Americans - merchants signed protest against modus vivendi. Light & Customs dues charged to American ship 'Potonac' & withdrawal of privilege of free shooting license.

Newfoundland - General 12. Cannot say what action M. Gouin will take. Possible to suspend action if Nfld. agrees to refrain form cutting or removing timber, pending settlement. Bond Hay Treaty likely to be ratified.

Colonial Office 308. Debate in British H. of C. on Reciprocity...Mr. Harcourt refrained from speaking, but was prepared to speak if the slightest attack had been made on Canadian Govt. - Asks for further communication on the subject. . .

Colonial Office 296. Disappointed with suggestion re White Ensign...but glad to receive telegram of 6th saying Hope to keep White Ensign untarnished, at any rate, till Imperial Conference. Obliged to refuse permission to go to W. Indies owing to questions of discipline on ships leaving territorial waters. . .

Colonial Office 318. Hopes nothing will prevent Sir W.L. from attending Imperial Conference...Status of Canadian Warships being settled...Reciprocity...does not believe it will result in U.S. absorption or Canada...General Arbitration Treaty...only obstacle to its acceptance in U.S. lack of Home Rule in Ireland...British Preference...re Lords Mayor...Mr. Redmond's invitation to the Prime Minister...will try and avoid exploiting of Dominion Premiers for political purposes...Political position at home...

Colonial Office 328. Hague Tribunal Recommendations...Sir W.L. strongly opposed to acceptance of recommendations, having - mistaken view of their interpretation...Sir C. Fitzpatrick supposed to have committed Great Britain to the acceptance of recommendations...Sir A. Aylesworth protests...Sir W.L. will only recognise the Agent of Canada, in the matter (Sir A. Aylesworth). Mr. Bryce is afraid refusal may affect F.O. & Newfoundland...

Colonial Office 265. Arrival of American Tariff CommissionersWish to receive assurance that Canada will not prohibit export of pulp...Canada friendly, but will not concede anything unless she gets fair return
